defs: the state or fact of existing or living; being.
(vīr .) vibrations in air, water, etc. that stimulate the auditory nerves and produce the sensation of hearing; the sound.
(Jain.) any of the soul, righteousness, unrighteousness, the sky.
= ಅಸ್ತಿತ್ವ.
the act, fact or state of being; existence; subsistence; entity.

the doctrine that concrete, individual existence takes precedence over abstract, conceptual essence and holds that human beings are totally free and responsible for their acts and that this responsibility is the source of their feelings of dread and anguish and also that it denies objective universal values and holding that a man must create values for himself through action and by living each moment to the full; existentialism.
an advocate or follower of the doctrine that human beings are morally free, and responsible for making their own system of values in an otherwise meaningless universe; an existentialist.
the base of a building; the foundation.
the initial ground work or fundamental principle on which something is founded; basis.
not firm; unstable; wavering.
the state of being unstable; want of stability; instability.
the plant (creeper) Cissus quadrangularis of Vitaceae family.
= ಅಸ್ತಿಭಾರ.
the first stone laid at the foundation of a building; the foundation stone.

an interjection expressing approval, consent, etc.; 'okay'; 'O.K.'; 'all right'.

to say 'okay' or 'all right'; to approve; to endorse.

the quality or state of being astatic.
a magnetic needle free from geo-magnetic influence; astatic needle.
any of the separate parts of the hard connective tissue forming the skeleton of most full-grown vertebrate animals; a bone.
(fig.) gone deep in to one's nature; deep-rooted; bred in the bone.
a deep-rooted disease.

any member (as Cephalaspis) of a group Silurian and Old Red Sandstone fishes or fish like animals, gen. cased in bony armour with undeveloped lower jaw, with flippers but not ordinary paired fins; ostracoderm.

the hard framework of an animal body, supporting the tissues and protecting the organs; esp. all the bones collectively or the bony framework, of a human being or other vertebrate animal ; the skeleton.
a supporting framework, as of a ship.
(fig.) a very lean or emaciated person, 4) (fig.) any bare skeleton like structure without life or essence.
a simple cellular rod, foreshadowing the spinal column persisting throughout life in many lower vertebrates, as the amphioxus, etc.; notochord.
the bundle of fibrous tissues joining the bones or cartilages; a ligament.
a break in a bone; a bone-fracture.
a member of a class of fish, which is supposed to be the predecessor of the class of fish with the bones (skeleton); osteichthyes.
infirm - a) (in standing or being established) not firm; unstable; wavering; insecure; b) not firm in mind or purpose; not resolute; vacillating.
lasting only for a time; transitory; temporary, not eternal.
a man who is not firm in mind or purpose.
a woman who is not firm in mind or purpose.

egoist - he who speaks only of himself or has excessive concern for his own interests; b) a man who advocates that we have proof of nothing but our own existence; c) a man who upholds the doctrine that self-interest is the proper goal of all human actions.
